There is no a priori evidence to suggest a psychiatric cause for any patient who may present with such an acute condition for non-psychiatric reasons. The following factors should make you fear a non-psychiatric aetiology. Once you have ruled them out, you can consider a psychiatric aetiology.

* Confusional syndrome
* Physical signs of dehydration
* Physical signs of infection
* Signs of cardiovascular or respiratory failure
* Urinary incontinence, faecal impaction
* abnormalities identified on neurological examination and general physical examination

question.title: What factors should make you suspect a non-psychiatric cause for a patient's agitation and acute delirium?

option_a.title: Confusional syndrome
option_a.description: A condition characterized by disorientation and confusion

option_b.title: Physical signs of dehydration
option_b.description: Visible symptoms of dehydration, such as dry mouth and dark urine

option_c.title: Signs of cardiovascular or respiratory failure
option_c.description: Indicators of heart or lung problems, such as difficulty breathing or chest pain

option_d.title: Urinary incontinence and faecal impaction
option_d.description: Loss of bladder or bowel control, which can be a sign of neurological disorders

correct_option.title: Physical signs of infection
correct_option.description: Visible signs of infection, such as redness, swelling, or pus
